Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male cult member in ‘grotesque’ style, wearing festival wreath headdress. Head only. Bald, consistent with representations of priests or followers of Ptah or Harpocrates. Mould-made and hollow, headdress was added after head was removed from the mould. Traces of white coating. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

There is a 'Roman' parallel (Dunand 1990, no. 519), however a number of figures in a similar style from related mould series are known from Naukratis Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge NA535, NA537, NA538, NA539; NA540; Fitzwilliam GR.36.1887; Ashmolean AN1896-1908-E.4758, AN1896-1908-E.4759; British Museum GR1886,0401.1426; Bailey 2008, 66, no.3188, dated to the 2nd century BC). These all have Ptolemaic parallels, probably from Alexandria (Louvre, Besques 1992, D/E 4572 Pl.87g) and favissa at Ras el-Soda, Alexandria, perhaps third to second century BC (Adriani 1952, pls 17, no. 2 and 19, no. 2, left). Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940- 1950), Alexandria. Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche- Orient. Paris. Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.542) (Phase 3)
